thread.title: How to see everything Twitter knows about you and download your tweet history

author: Todd Haselton
title: How to see everything Twitter knows about you and download your tweet history
text:
Twitter knows a lot about you, including where you've been and the advertisers you're interested in. We're going to show you how to download that information.
It's important to understand what social media companies know about you, particularly in the wake of the leak of Facebook data , where political analytics Cambridge Analytica obtained information on more than 50 million users.
Before we get started, want to know what Facebook and Google know about you?
How to download everything Facebook knows about you. How to download everything Google knows about you. After some digging, I discovered that Twitter knows:
What devices I use for Twitter. When and where I was when I tweeted. The advertising topics I'm interested in. Hundreds of applications I've downloaded on my smartphone. Every tweet I've ever posted. Finding everything Twitter knows about you is easy. Just do this: Open your profile from a web browser. Click your picture in the top-right corner next to the tweet button. Select "Settings and Privacy." Choose "Your Twitter data" from the left menu. Dig through this information. Here's what you'll see: This shows when I created my account, down to the exact minute. My gender, my age, the languages I speak (I only speak English, however) and my profile location.
It also shows where I'm logged in: Places I've been recently: Topics and people I'm interested in: Interests that Twitter's partners have access to: This is interesting because I just bought a Jeep Wrangler but had no idea that Twitter knew I was searching for cars. It also seems to have access to some sort of shopping list data, though I'm not sure where it's from. Twitter says this is gathered from "shopping decisions, lifestyle, and other online and offline behaviors."
Hundreds of applications that have access to my Twitter data: Here's what that means: "When you connect a third-party application to your Twitter account, you are granting that application access to use your account. Depending on its permissions, an authorized application may be able to use your account in various ways, including reading your Tweets, seeing who you follow, updating your profile, posting Tweets on your behalf, accessing your Direct Messages, or seeing your email address."
Like Facebook, there are also contacts uploaded from my phone, which I never knew I did: Download a copy of your tweets and data: At the bottom of the page, select "Request your data." It takes a couple of hours and may end up in your spam folder. For me, I found this was most valuable for seeing every tweet I'd ever posted, all the way back to the day I joined in 2007. Look at them all:
